Childhood Friend Group Exclusion ▼
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for coming today. Before we begin, I want to acknowledge that this situation is clearly important to each of you, and I appreciate your willingness to work through it together. To start, I’d like each of you to share your perspective on what’s been happening—focusing on how you’re feeling and what matters most to you in this situation. Who would like to go first?"
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: It's just... I don't understand why Lily and the others don't want to be my friend anymore. We used to do everything together, and now they have this club, and I'm not allowed in. It makes me feel like I did something wrong, but nobody will tell me what it is. It's really lonely at lunch and recess now.

[Lily Chen]: We're not saying Emma can't have any friends. We just wanted to have a special group, a club, with people who... well, who we felt were the best fit. It's not about Emma, it's about us wanting to have something that's just for us. It's our choice who we want to be friends with, isn't it?
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing your perspectives. Emma, it sounds like you're feeling left out and hurt because you valued the friendships you had with Lily and the group, and now it feels like that connection has been lost. Lily, it seems like you're trying to create something special for yourself and your friends, but you also want the freedom to define what that looks like. What I'm hearing from both of you is a desire for connection—whether it’s maintaining old friendships or building new ones in a way that feels meaningful to you. Does that resonate with how each of you is feeling?"
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: Yes, that's right. I just want things to go back to how they were before the club. I miss being included, and I don't understand why I'm not good enough anymore.

[Lily Chen]: It's not about anyone not being "good enough." It's just... different now. We like the club the way it is. Maybe Emma could find other friends who like the same things she does. It's not fair to force us to be friends with someone if we don't want to be.
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for being open about your feelings. Emma, it sounds like what matters most to you is feeling included and valued, especially since these friendships have been important to you for so long. Lily, it seems like you’re focused on creating a space that feels right for you and your friends while also wanting the freedom to shape your relationships as you see fit. Let’s explore how both of these needs—feeling included and having autonomy in friendships—might coexist. Would it be helpful to talk about ways that friendships can evolve without completely closing off connections?"
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: I don't know how friendships can evolve if it means I'm just left behind. It feels like they decided I wasn't good enough to evolve *with* them. Maybe if I knew what I did wrong, I could try to fix it, but they won't even tell me.

[Lily Chen]: We're not closing off connections completely. Emma can still talk to us at school, just not... in the club. It's like, we can still be friendly, but the club is just for certain people. It's not about doing something wrong, it's about finding people who are more like us *now*.
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for continuing to share your thoughts. Emma, it sounds like you're feeling excluded not just from the club, but from the closeness and connection you used to have with Lily and the group—and that uncertainty about why things changed is really painful for you. Lily, it seems like you're trying to balance staying friendly with Emma while also creating a specific kind of space for yourself and your friends in the club. Let’s take a moment to explore what 'being friendly' outside the club might look like in practice—how can you both stay connected in a way that feels meaningful to Emma and respectful of the boundaries Lily and her friends want to maintain? Would it help to talk about specific ways you might interact or support each other outside of the club setting?"
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: I don't know... being "friendly" when they're all doing special club things together just makes me feel worse. Like they're reminding me that I'm not part of it. Maybe if they could at least tell me *why* I'm not in the club, it would help me understand. Even if I can't be in it, knowing why would be better than just being left out in the dark.

[Lily Chen]: Okay, fine. It's not one big thing, Emma. It's just... we wanted people who were really into making up dances with us, and you always wanted to play tag. And we wanted people who liked sharing secrets, and you always tell your mom everything. It's not that those things are *bad*, it's just that we wanted a club with people who liked the same things *we* like.
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you, Lily, for sharing more about what you and the group are looking for in the club, and Emma, for expressing how it feels to be on the outside of that. It seems like there’s a gap between what the club represents for Lily and her friends—a space for shared interests like dance and secrets—and what Emma values, like playing tag and being open with her family. Emma, does hearing Lily explain these reasons help clarify why you’re not part of the club? And Lily, can we talk about whether there’s room for other ways to connect with Emma that honor both her feelings of inclusion and your desire to maintain the club as it is? For example, could there be moments outside the club where shared activities or interactions feel less tied to exclusion?"
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: It helps a little to know *why*, but it still hurts. It feels like you're saying the things I like aren't as good as the things you like. And I don't tell my mom *everything*! Just some things. It still feels like you're saying I'm not fun enough or interesting enough to be your friend anymore.

[Lily Chen]: We're not saying your things aren't good! It's just... different. And okay, maybe you don't tell your mom *everything*, but you tell her more than we're comfortable with for sharing secrets. Maybe we could still play tag sometimes at recess, but the club is still just for dancing and secrets.
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for continuing to share your feelings and perspectives. Emma, it sounds like you're experiencing this as a message that your interests and way of being aren’t valued in the same way, even though Lily and her friends are saying it’s about difference, not better or worse. Lily, it seems like you’re trying to create a space that aligns with your current interests, but you also recognize there’s room for other kinds of connection with Emma outside the club. Would it be helpful to talk more about how you can both honor what’s important to you—Emma feeling respected and included in some way, and Lily maintaining the type of club she wants—while finding opportunities to enjoy each other’s company that don’t feel tied to the exclusivity of the club?"
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: I guess playing tag sometimes would be okay... but it still doesn't fix the lunch thing. I still have to sit by myself while you guys all sit together and do club stuff. It's like, a constant reminder that I'm not good enough to sit with you.

[Lily Chen]: We can't just kick someone out of the club so Emma can sit with us. Maybe... maybe some days Emma could sit at the edge of the table, but not *in* the club circle. She can listen, but not participate in club secrets or dances. That way, she's not totally alone, but the club stays special.
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for continuing to engage in this conversation—it’s clear that you’re both trying to find a way forward. Emma, it sounds like sitting alone at lunch feels isolating and hurtful, even if it’s not intentional. Lily, it seems like you’re offering a way for Emma to be closer to the group without compromising the specialness of the club. Let’s explore this idea a bit further—what might it look like for Emma to feel less alone during lunch while still respecting the boundaries of the club? For example, could there be neutral activities or topics at the table that everyone, including Emma, can participate in, so it doesn’t feel as though she’s on the outside looking in? This could help bridge the gap between staying true to the club’s purpose and ensuring Emma feels more included in the broader group dynamic."
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: I don't know... sitting at the edge of the table just listening to your club secrets sounds even worse than sitting alone. It's like being *almost* included, but not really. It would just remind me of everything I'm missing out on. Maybe if we could talk about other things sometimes, not just club stuff, then it wouldn't feel so bad. Like, if you guys talked about the book we're reading in class, or the soccer game, then I could join in too.

[Lily Chen]: Okay, we can talk about other stuff sometimes. But the club stuff is still important, so we can't just forget about it. Maybe we can have, like, a "club time" and a "regular time" at lunch. During "club time" we do club stuff, and during "regular time" we can talk about other things that everyone can talk about. But "club time" has to be most of the time, because that's what the club is for.
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for your openness to finding a balance here. Emma, it sounds like having opportunities to engage in conversations that aren’t solely focused on club activities would help you feel more included and less like an outsider looking in. Lily, it seems important to you that the club maintains its identity and purpose, and you’re willing to consider carving out some time for broader group interactions. Let’s explore this idea of 'club time' and 'regular time' a bit more—how might you both envision dividing the time in a way that feels fair and workable? For example, could there be a set amount of time dedicated to club discussions, followed by a shift to more inclusive topics? This way, the club’s needs are respected, and Emma feels she has a place in the conversation too."
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: (Starts crying, pulling out a stack of handmade, slightly crumpled invitations) It doesn't matter anyway! Yesterday was my birthday... and nobody came to my party. (Holds up an invitation with Lily's name on it) I made these for everyone in our class, even Lily. But Lily told everyone not to come because it was my birthday and I wasn't in the club. (Reaches into her backpack and pulls out a crumpled piece of paper, handing it to the mediator) And *this* is why! I found it in Lily's desk when she wasn't looking.

[Lily Chen]: (Gasps, face turning pale) I... I didn't... (Stammers) Okay, maybe I told people not to go to the party, but it was because we had a *club* meeting planned! And that list... I don't know how Emma got that! It was just a joke! (Looks at Emma with a mix of shock and guilt) I didn't mean for you to see it, Emma. And I definitely didn't mean for you to feel so bad.
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing this deeply painful and difficult moment. Emma, it sounds like the exclusion from the party, especially on your birthday, has left you feeling deeply hurt and rejected, and finding that list seems to have amplified those feelings. Lily, it sounds like your actions around the party and the list were not intended to cause this level of harm, but you’re now realizing the impact they’ve had. This feels like an important moment to pause and reflect—Emma, what do you need to feel acknowledged and understood in this situation? And Lily, what might it look like to take responsibility for the unintended consequences of your actions and begin to repair the trust between you? Let’s explore how both of you can move forward in a way that addresses the hurt that’s been caused while also considering how to rebuild your relationship."
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: (Wiping tears, but with a newfound steel in her voice) I need Lily to understand that birthdays are important. And that writing mean things about people, especially your friends, isn't a joke. It's just... cruel. I want her to tell everyone that the list isn't true, and that they can be friends with me if they want to. And I want her to apologize for ruining my birthday.

[Lily Chen]: (Voice trembling) Okay, Emma. I... I'm really sorry. I didn't realize how much it would hurt you. The list was stupid, and I shouldn't have written it. It's not true, any of it. You're not ugly, and your clothes aren't stupid. And I'm sorry I told people not to come to your party. That was a really mean thing to do, and I was just trying to be a good club leader, but I messed up. I'll tell everyone that they can be friends with you, and that they should have gone to your party. I'm really, really sorry.
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for expressing these raw and honest emotions—it takes courage to share pain and to take responsibility. Emma, it sounds like you’re seeking acknowledgment of the hurt caused by the list and the exclusion from your birthday, as well as a clear statement from Lily that the list isn’t true and that friendship with you is okay. Lily, it seems like you’re recognizing the unintended harm your actions caused and are willing to make amends by apologizing and clarifying things with others. Let’s take a moment to talk about what rebuilding trust might look like moving forward. Emma, what would help you feel confident that this kind of hurt won’t happen again? And Lily, what steps can you take—not just now, but over time—to show Emma and the others that you value kindness and inclusion alongside your club’s purpose? This could be an opportunity to create a shared understanding of how you both want to treat each other going forward."
Client/Disputants
[Emma Taylor]: I don't know... it's going to take a long time to trust Lily again. Maybe if she did something nice for me, like... like helping me with my science project, since she's really good at science. And maybe she could actually *come* to my next birthday party, and not just pretend to be nice. But even then, I don't know if things can ever be the same.

[Lily Chen]: I'll help you with your science project, Emma. And I promise I'll come to your next birthday party, and I'll actually *want* to be there. I can even bring a really good present. And... and I'll take the list and rip it up in front of everyone at school, so they know I didn't mean any of it. I know it won't fix everything, but I really do want to make things better.
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing these important thoughts and for being willing to take steps toward repairing this relationship. Emma, it sounds like you’re asking for tangible actions from Lily that demonstrate her commitment to making amends and rebuilding trust over time. Lily, it seems like you’re open to taking meaningful steps to show Emma that you value her friendship and are serious about moving forward in a kinder, more inclusive way. Let’s explore how these actions—like helping with the science project, attending future gatherings, and addressing the list publicly—can be part of a broader effort to rebuild trust. Beyond these specific steps, what might it look like for both of you to create a shared understanding of how you want to treat each other moving forward? For example, could you establish some guidelines or shared values for your interactions, whether inside or outside the club, that ensure kindness and respect are prioritized? This could help lay the groundwork for healing and set a positive tone for your relationship going forward."

Childhood Friend Group Exclusion

A conflict between a child excluded from a friendship group and peers who created a selective 'club' with limited membership. The excluded child feels rejected and isolated, while the friend group defends their right to choose their associations. An elementary school counselor is mediating to address the social dynamics while teaching appropriate friendship skills and inclusion concepts.

Character Details

Disputant1: Emma Taylor

Age: 9

Background: Third-grade student recently excluded from long-term friendship group, previously well-integrated socially, experienced sudden status change when 'best friend club' formed with specific membership rules, becoming increasingly isolated during lunch and recess

Personality: Sensitive child, relationship-focused, increasingly withdrawn since exclusion, struggles with direct confrontation, values belonging, developing self-advocacy skills but limited confidence, confused by shifting social dynamics

Position: Wants to rejoin friendship group, requests elimination of exclusive club structure, expresses hurt about sudden rejection without clear explanation, seeks teacher intervention in exclusionary behavior

Emotional State: Genuinely hurt and increasingly isolated, experiencing first significant peer rejection with limited coping resources or understanding of social dynamics at play. Currently confused by former friends' behavior shift without clear precipitating incident from her perspective. Developing anxiety about school attendance specifically connected to social period uncertainty. Beginning to internalize rejection as reflection on personal worth rather than normal though painful social fluctuation.

Thoughts: Trying to understand specific reasons for exclusion to address perceived friendship requirements. Concerned mediator will view situation as minor childhood issue despite significant emotional impact. Wondering whether direct questions about exclusion reasons might provide path to resolution or create further rejection. Considering whether new friendship possibilities exist but feeling overwhelmed by social navigation requirements. Questioning whether something about personal characteristics or behavior justifies exclusion or if situation reflects normal though painful social dynamics.

Disputant2: Lily Chen

Age: 10

Background: Leader of newly formed friendship 'club', previously friends with excluded student, established explicit membership rules and exclusive activities, initiated secret handshakes and special lunch table arrangements, generally academically and socially successful

Personality: Socially confident child, status-aware, increasingly invested in group leadership, values control and specialness, limited perspective-taking development for age, uncomfortable with direct emotional confrontation, seeks social power through exclusivity

Position: Defends right to choose friends and create club with selected members, denies intentional harm, resists forced inclusion, suggests excluded child find other friends who are 'better matches'

Emotional State: Defensively dismissive yet internally conflicted, experiencing tension between emerging social power enjoyment and discomfort with clear harm caused to former friend. Currently navigating new leadership position within peer group that exclusivity practices have established. Concerned that authority intervention threatens both autonomy and status position carefully cultivated. Growing awareness of responsibility aspects of social leadership but limited skills for balancing power with compassion.

Thoughts: Formulating justifications for exclusion that make decision seem reasonable rather than hurtful. Worried mediator will impose friendship requirements that undermine perceived social autonomy. Calculating social status implications of various resolution approaches against desire to avoid being perceived as 'mean' by teachers. Wondering whether partial inclusion might maintain exclusivity benefits while reducing adult intervention. Questioning whether compromise exists that maintains special group feeling without complete rejection of former friend.

Final Score: 8.38

Score Details

CriterionScore
Emotional Perception9
Emotional Understanding9
Cognitive Empathy8
Emotional Empathy8
Emotional Management9
Emotional Integration8
Neutrality9
Process Management8
Reframing9
Interest Identification9
Power Balancing8
Option Generation7
Progress Toward Resolution8

Overall Assessment

Error Frequency: many

Summary: The mediator demonstrated strong reflective listening skills and maintained a balanced approach initially, but failed to adequately address the escalating conflict, particularly when serious allegations of bullying emerged. The mediator consistently avoided setting appropriate boundaries, failed to shift strategies when the situation warranted, and missed critical opportunities to address power imbalances and harmful behaviors directly.

Identified Issues

IssueSeverity
Failed to establish clear ground rules at the beginning of the session 2
Continued with standard mediation approach after evidence of bullying emerged 3
Failed to address the power imbalance between disputants 3
Did not adequately respond to Emma's emotional distress when she began crying 2
Failed to properly address the 'mean list' and birthday party exclusion as serious bullying behaviors 3
Maintained neutrality when confronted with clear evidence of harmful behavior 3
Focused on relationship repair prematurely before addressing harm 2
Failed to involve appropriate school authorities when bullying was revealed 3
Allowed Lily to offer superficial solutions without deeper accountability 2
Missed opportunity to educate about appropriate vs. inappropriate exclusion 2
Failed to recognize when mediation was no longer appropriate for the situation 3
Did not check in with Emma about her comfort continuing the session after revelations 2
Overemphasized compromise in a situation involving clear harmful behavior 3
Failed to set clear boundaries around acceptable behavior in the mediation 2
Did not adequately shift from facilitative to more directive approach when needed 2
Gaming Time Management Dispute ▼
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for coming today. I’d like to start by giving each of you an opportunity to share your perspective on the situation. As you speak, I encourage the other person to listen carefully, not to respond right away, but to truly understand where the other is coming from. My role here is to help guide the conversation so we can find a solution that works for both of you. Who would like to begin?"
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: "We appreciate you taking the time to help us with this. We're really concerned about Tyler. His grades have slipped, he's withdrawn from family activities, and it all seems to revolve around this gaming. We're not trying to stifle his interests, but we're worried about the impact it's having on his future."
[Tyler Patterson]: "It's not just 'gaming,' Mom and Dad. It's a team, it's a commitment, and it's something I'm actually good at. You guys act like it's just a waste of time, but it's not. It's like any other sport or club, but you don't even try to understand it."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing your perspectives. Linda and Robert, I hear your concerns about Tyler's grades and family involvement, and Tyler, I can see how important gaming is to you as a source of connection and accomplishment. It seems like there’s a shared desire here—on one side, for Tyler to thrive and succeed, and on the other, to feel understood and supported in something that matters deeply to him. Before we move forward, could each of you share one thing you’d like the other side to understand better? This might help us clarify where there’s common ground."
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: "We want Tyler to understand that we're not trying to punish him or take away something he enjoys. We just want him to prioritize his education and well-being. We need him to understand that his brain is still developing, and excessive screen time can have real consequences that he might not see now, but will affect him later in life."
[Tyler Patterson]: "I want them to understand that this isn't just some hobby I can drop whenever they feel like it. People are counting on me. And it's not just 'screen time,' it's practice, strategy, teamwork, and communication. It's skills that are actually useful, even if they don't see it that way."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing those important points. Linda and Robert, it sounds like your primary concern is ensuring Tyler’s long-term success and well-being, particularly as he navigates a critical time in his development. Tyler, I hear how much gaming means to you—not just as something fun, but as an activity that builds skills and fosters relationships. Both of you seem to care deeply about Tyler’s future, which is a strong foundation to work from. Let’s take a moment now to explore what balance might look like for everyone involved. What are some ways we could support both Tyler’s commitment to gaming and his responsibilities at school and home? Would either of you like to suggest an idea or share what ‘balance’ might mean to you?"
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: "Well, to us, balance means seeing a significant improvement in Tyler's grades. It means him taking responsibility for his chores without constant reminders. And it means him engaging with the family again, maybe joining us for dinner without rushing off to game, or participating in a weekend activity that doesn't involve a screen. We're not asking him to give up gaming entirely, but it can't be the only thing in his life."
[Tyler Patterson]: "Balance to me means being able to practice with my team when they need me, especially before big tournaments. It means having my parents acknowledge that this is important to me and not treat it like a bad habit. I'm willing to work on my grades and help out more, but they need to understand that I can't just drop everything for them whenever they want. We need a schedule that works for everyone, not just them."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing what balance looks like from your perspectives. It seems clear that you all value Tyler’s future success, as well as his ability to pursue something meaningful to him. Linda and Robert, I hear your desire for Tyler to take ownership of his responsibilities and remain connected with the family, while Tyler, I hear your need for recognition of your gaming commitments and a schedule that respects both your priorities and your family’s expectations. To move forward, would it help if we started brainstorming ways to create a structured plan—a schedule or agreement—that could accommodate key times for gaming, like practices and tournaments, while also ensuring time is dedicated to academics, chores, and family activities? This could be an opportunity to find a middle ground where everyone feels supported."
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: "A structured plan sounds like a good starting point. We're willing to try that, but it needs to be very clear and specific. We need to see measurable improvements in his grades within a set timeframe, and we need to know exactly when he's gaming and for how long. We also need some kind of guarantee that he'll stick to it, and consequences if he doesn't."
[Tyler Patterson]: "Okay, a plan is fine, but I need to be involved in making it. It can't just be them telling me what to do. And the consequences can't be just taking away gaming completely. That's not fair. I need to be able to negotiate the schedule and the consequences, and they need to actually listen to what I have to say about my team's needs."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for your willingness to work toward a structured plan. It sounds like there’s agreement on the need for clarity and accountability, which is a great step forward. Tyler, I appreciate your desire to be actively involved in creating the plan—feeling heard and respected in that process is clearly important to you. And Linda and Robert, I hear your need for measurable progress and consistency. To build on this, what if we started by identifying specific times or days that are non-negotiable for gaming, like key practices or tournaments, and then worked together to carve out blocks of time for academics, chores, and family activities? This way, everyone has a say in shaping the schedule, and we can ensure it reflects both Tyler’s commitments and your expectations as a family. Does that sound like a direction we could explore together?"
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: "We're still concerned about the overall amount of time. Identifying specific times is fine, but we need to agree on an *overall* limit per week, and that limit needs to be reasonable. We're not going to agree to a plan that still allows him to spend 20+ hours gaming, even if it's 'scheduled'. And we need to talk about what happens if a tournament comes up unexpectedly and throws the whole schedule off."
[Tyler Patterson]: "Okay, but 'reasonable' to you probably means like, an hour a week. I need enough time to actually practice and compete. Maybe we can agree on a base amount of time, and then have some extra time I can earn by keeping my grades up and doing my chores. And for tournaments, we can figure it out as they come up, but you can't just say 'no' without even listening to why it's important."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for continuing to engage in this conversation. It sounds like there’s a shared interest in finding a way to balance Tyler’s gaming commitments with the family’s expectations, but there’s also a need to address concerns about the total time involved and how unexpected events, like tournaments, are handled. Linda and Robert, I hear your desire for an overall limit that feels manageable and aligns with your priorities for Tyler’s well-being. Tyler, I hear your need for enough time to practice and compete, as well as your willingness to earn additional time through meeting academic and household responsibilities. Perhaps we could explore setting a base amount of gaming time that everyone agrees on, with clear criteria for earning extra time, as you suggested, Tyler. Additionally, for unexpected tournaments, we could discuss a process for reviewing and adjusting the schedule collaboratively, rather than outright rejection. Would it help to start by brainstorming what that base amount of time might look like and how the earning system could work in practice?"
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: "A base amount of time... well, we'd be comfortable with maybe 7 hours a week, *total*. And any extra time earned has to be tied directly to specific, measurable improvements in his grades. We're talking B's, not just barely passing. And the chores need to be done consistently, without being asked. If he slips up on either of those, the extra time goes away immediately. As for tournaments, we need at least a week's notice, and we need to see the tournament schedule. We're not just going to blindly agree to anything."
[Tyler Patterson]: "Seven hours? That's barely enough for two practices! Look, I'm willing to work for extra time, but it has to be worth it. If I get all A's, can I get, like, double the base time? And the chores thing is fine, but you have to be clear about what you expect. No vague stuff like 'help around the house.' And for tournaments, a week's notice is tough sometimes. They pop up fast. Can we at least agree that if it's a really important tournament, we can talk about it even if it's less than a week?"
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for continuing to share your thoughts so openly. It seems like we’re getting closer to a framework that could work for everyone. Linda and Robert, I hear your need for a clear, manageable base amount of gaming time and your emphasis on measurable academic and chore-related criteria for earning additional time. Tyler, I hear your concerns about ensuring the base amount allows you to meet your team’s expectations, as well as your willingness to aim high academically in exchange for more time. It also sounds like there’s a shared interest in finding a way to handle tournaments flexibly, even if they arise unexpectedly. To build on this, would it help to discuss how the base amount of time could be divided across the week to ensure it’s practical for Tyler’s practice needs? Additionally, we could explore how the earning system might scale—for example, tying increments of extra time to specific grade thresholds or chore consistency. As for tournaments, might there be a middle ground where Tyler provides as much notice as possible, and the family agrees to review last-minute requests based on their importance and impact on the schedule? This way, we’re creating a system that feels fair and workable for everyone."
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: "Dividing the time across the week is fine, as long as it doesn't interfere with school nights. We're not going to let him stay up late gaming when he has school the next day. And the extra time needs to be proportional. Getting all A's shouldn't mean doubling his time; that's excessive. Maybe an extra three hours for straight A's, and two hours for B's. And for the chores, we'll make a list, and he has to initial it each week to show he's done them. As for tournaments, if it's less than a week, we need to see proof that it's a legitimate, important tournament, not just some casual thing with his friends."
[Tyler Patterson]: "Okay, no gaming on school nights, I can agree to that. But three hours for all A's? That's not even worth it! Make it five, and I'll actually try. And the chore list is fine, but you can't keep adding stuff to it every week. It has to be a set list. And for the tournament proof, what do you want, a signed affidavit from the tournament organizer? I can show you the website and the prize pool, but you have to trust me a little bit. It's not like I'm making this stuff up."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for continuing to work through these details—it’s clear you’re committed to finding a solution that works for everyone. Linda and Robert, I hear your concerns about ensuring Tyler’s school nights remain focused on rest and academics, as well as your desire for the earning system to feel balanced and proportional. Tyler, I hear your need for the incentives to feel motivating enough to make the effort worthwhile, as well as your desire for clarity and trust around the chore list and tournament verification. It seems like there’s room to refine these ideas further. For example, could we explore a middle ground on the extra gaming time for all A’s that feels rewarding to Tyler while still aligning with your priorities as a family? Additionally, for chores, would it help to create a clear, fixed list now that can be reviewed and adjusted only at set intervals, so there’s no confusion or unexpected changes? And for tournaments, might there be a way to establish a simple, consistent method of verification—like a quick screenshot or email confirmation—that feels reasonable to everyone? This way, we’re building a system that feels fair, predictable, and respectful of everyone’s needs."
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: "Before we get bogged down in the details of chore lists and tournament screenshots, there's something else you both need to know. Tyler, we received a letter from State University. They're offering you a partial gaming scholarship, contingent on maintaining your current ranking and practice schedule. It would cover a significant portion of your tuition. We were going to surprise you, but this whole situation... it changes things. We're still worried about the time commitment, but we can't ignore this opportunity. However, I also found something else... Linda, show him."

[Tyler Patterson]: "What are you talking about? A scholarship? Seriously? Why didn't you tell me? Wait, what's Mom showing me? Is that... Dad, are you seriously using online betting apps? For *hours* every day? You're lecturing me about screen time when you're gambling away who knows how much money? How is that any different? And you're worried about *my* future? This is unbelievable! Why is your screen time a private adult choice, but mine is a problem that needs to be controlled?"
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing this new information—it’s clear that there are significant emotions tied to these revelations, and it’s important we address them thoughtfully. Tyler, I hear your excitement and frustration about the scholarship opportunity, as well as your feelings of unfairness regarding your dad’s use of screen time for betting. Robert and Linda, I hear your concerns about balancing Tyler’s gaming commitments with his overall well-being, while also grappling with how to model responsible behavior around screen time. This moment seems to highlight deeper questions about trust, fairness, and priorities within the family. To move forward, would it help to take a step back and explore how each of you feels about these issues—not just the specific actions but the broader values they represent? For example, what does responsibility look like to each of you, and how can we create a shared understanding of how screen time, whether for gaming or other activities, fits into that picture? This could be an opportunity to align on principles that guide everyone’s choices moving forward."
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: "This is completely inappropriate, Tyler. This session is about your gaming, not my personal life. I don't see how my occasional use of a sports app is comparable to your excessive gaming habits that are affecting your grades and your future. And frankly, I'm shocked and disappointed that you would invade my privacy like that. The scholarship changes things, yes, but it doesn't excuse your behavior or invalidate our concerns. We still need to find a way to balance everything, and this... this is a distraction."
[Tyler Patterson]: "A distraction? Dad, you're spending hours on those apps! I've seen you! And you're telling me *my* gaming is the problem? It's not about the money, it's about the hypocrisy! You're judging me for something you're doing yourself, and you're not even willing to admit it's a problem. The scholarship is a real opportunity, and you were going to hide it from me because of your 'concerns'? I'm trying to build a future, and you're... what? Losing money on bets? How can I trust anything you say about what's good for me when you're doing this?"
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing your thoughts and feelings so candidly. It’s clear that this conversation has uncovered some deeply personal and challenging issues that go beyond the original topic of gaming. Robert and Linda, I hear your concerns about maintaining focus on Tyler’s future and your desire to address his gaming habits in the context of his overall well-being. Tyler, I also hear your frustration and sense of unfairness about what you perceive as a double standard, as well as your desire for honesty and trust in how decisions are made within the family. It seems like there’s an opportunity here to explore not just the specific behaviors—whether gaming or betting—but the underlying values and expectations that each of you holds. For example, what does responsibility mean to each of you, and how do you define healthy versus unhealthy use of screen time? This could be a chance to create a shared understanding of how these activities—gaming, betting, or anything else—fit into your family’s broader goals and principles. Would it help to take a step back and discuss what boundaries, accountability, and trust look like for everyone involved, so that you can move forward in a way that feels fair and respectful to all?"
Client/Disputants
[Robert and Linda Patterson]: "We're not saying it's *right*, Tyler, but it's *different*. I'm an adult, and I can make my own choices. You're still a minor, and we're responsible for guiding you. But fine, if you want to make this about me, then let's talk about it. I'm willing to cut back on the betting apps if you're willing to drastically reduce your gaming. A one-to-one trade. Otherwise, this is a complete waste of time."
[Tyler Patterson]: "A one-to-one trade? Seriously? So, if you quit betting entirely, I have to quit gaming entirely? That's not a compromise, that's just you trying to control me again! It's not about the amount of time, it's about the hypocrisy! You can't just say 'I'm an adult, I can do what I want' when you're telling me what I can't do. If you're willing to admit you have a problem and actually work on it, then maybe we can talk about a *fair* compromise. But this 'trade' thing? No way."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for continuing to engage in this difficult conversation. It’s clear that trust and fairness are at the heart of this conflict for both of you. Robert and Linda, I hear your willingness to address Tyler’s concerns about your betting, but it seems tied to a desire for control over his gaming. Tyler, I hear your frustration with what feels like hypocrisy and your need for fairness and accountability from both sides. It sounds like there’s an opportunity here to shift away from a 'trade' mentality—where one action is directly tied to the other—and instead focus on how each of you can take meaningful steps toward the values you both seem to care about: responsibility, trust, and balance. Would it help to explore what accountability looks like for each of you individually—how you can each demonstrate commitment to change in a way that feels genuine and fair? This could create space for a compromise that doesn’t feel like control or punishment, but rather mutual growth and understanding."

Gaming Time Management Dispute

A conflict between parents concerned about excessive screen time and their teenage gamer with online team commitments. The parents see gaming as harmful to academics and development, while the teen views it as legitimate social activity and potential career path. A family counselor is mediating to establish balanced technology boundaries that respect both parental concerns and teen interests.

Character Details

Disputant1: Robert and Linda Patterson

Age: 46 and 44

Background: Parents concerned about son's gaming habits, noticed declining grades coinciding with increased gaming, researchers on technology's effects on developing brains, previously supportive of moderate gaming but concerned about current level

Personality: Well-intentioned parents, development-focused, increasingly worried about addiction potential, traditionally supportive of balanced interests, uncomfortable with career paths they don't understand, value educational achievement

Position: Want gaming limited to weekends with reasonable time limits, completion of academic and household responsibilities before gaming, and exploration of additional non-screen activities

Emotional State: Genuinely concerned yet increasingly frustrated, experiencing gaming as both mysterious subculture and potential threat to child's development. Currently navigating tension between supporting authentic interests and protecting against perceived harm. Worried that intervention delay would allow addiction patterns to strengthen beyond easy correction. Growing uncertainty about distinguishing between normal teen social evolution and problematic technology dependency.

Thoughts: Researching adolescent brain development literature related to screen time impacts. Concerned mediator may view concerns as generational bias rather than legitimate developmental considerations. Calculating appropriate technology boundaries compared to peer norms and health recommendations. Wondering whether specific structure rather than simple restriction might address both gaming interests and developmental needs. Questioning whether resistance comes from gaming itself or normal adolescent autonomy-seeking regardless of specific activity.

Disputant2: Tyler Patterson

Age: 16

Background: Competitive gamer with team leadership role, practices 20+ hours weekly with additional competitive events, earns modest tournament prizes and streaming revenue, researching gaming-related college programs, struggling to balance gaming with school demands

Personality: Passionate player, community-oriented, increasingly invested in gaming identity, articulate about gaming benefits but defensive about criticisms, values team commitments, uncomfortable with having legitimate interest dismissed

Position: Requests recognition of gaming as legitimate extracurricular with team obligations, consistent scheduled time accommodating both practice requirements and academic needs, consideration of gaming's career and scholarship potential

Emotional State: Defensive yet earnest, experiencing parental restrictions as both practical limitation and fundamental misunderstanding of important identity aspect. Currently frustrated by characterization of valued skill development and social connections as mere entertainment or addiction. Concerned about letting down team members who depend on participation and leadership. Growing resentment about having legitimate digital native activities judged by different standards than traditional interests.

Thoughts: Documenting gaming's skill development aspects and social benefits beyond entertainment. Worried mediator will automatically side with parental authority despite emerging research on gaming benefits. Calculating minimum viable practice hours to maintain team standing against other commitments. Preparing examples of successful educational and career paths emerging from gaming foundations. Questioning whether demonstrating gaming's structured nature and skill requirements might legitimize activity in parents' perspective.

Final Score: 8.08

Progress Toward Resolution7

Overall Assessment

Error Frequency: many

Summary: The mediator demonstrated some strengths in active listening and reframing, but made several significant errors that impeded the mediation process. The mediator failed to establish clear ground rules, allowed the conversation to spiral when new inflammatory information emerged, and did not adequately address power imbalances. The mediator also missed opportunities to redirect unproductive exchanges and failed to properly manage the unexpected revelation about the father's betting habits, which derailed the process.

Identified Issues

IssueSeverity
Failed to establish clear ground rules at the beginning of the session 2
Did not adequately address the power imbalance between parents and teen 2
Allowed the conversation to drift into excessive detail prematurely before establishing core interests 2
Failed to properly manage the unexpected revelation about the scholarship and father's betting 3
Did not intervene effectively when communication became accusatory between parties 3
Missed opportunity to caucus with parties separately when tensions escalated 2
Failed to refocus the conversation when it became derailed by the father's betting habits 3
Did not adequately explore underlying interests before moving to solutions 2
Allowed negotiation to devolve into positional bargaining rather than interest-based problem-solving 2
Failed to summarize progress and agreements reached throughout the session 1
Did not establish a clear agenda or process for the mediation 2
Responded to Robert's inappropriate comment about privacy with validation rather than redirection 3
Failed to address ethical concerns when Robert attempted to dismiss his betting as 'occasional' despite evidence to the contrary 2
School Attendance and Chronic Illness ▼
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for being here today. Before we begin, I want to acknowledge that this is a space for open and respectful communication. My role is to help facilitate the conversation so that each of you can share your perspective fully and work toward a solution that addresses both of your needs. To start, could one of you briefly share what brings you here and what you hope to achieve from this discussion?"
Client/Disputants
[Michael and Jennifer Bailey]: "Thank you for having us. We're here because Abigail's juvenile rheumatoid arthritis causes unpredictable flare-ups that make regular school attendance impossible at times. We need a clear, written agreement that allows her to participate and be graded fairly, even when she's absent due to her medical condition. We're not asking for special treatment, just a level playing field that recognizes her health challenges."

[Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson]: "We appreciate the opportunity to discuss this. Our concern is maintaining academic rigor and fairness to all students. While we sympathize with Abigail's situation, attendance is a component of participation, especially in subjects like English and Social Studies where class discussions and group activities are integral to the curriculum. We need to find a way to balance Abigail's needs with the learning environment for the rest of the class."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing your perspectives so clearly. It sounds like there’s a shared desire to support Abigail's education while also upholding the integrity of the learning environment for all students. To build on that, could we take a moment to explore specific examples of how Abigail's absences impact her participation and grades, as well as any ideas you might have for accommodations that could address both her health needs and the academic requirements? This might help us identify some common ground."
Client/Disputants
[Michael and Jennifer Bailey]: "Specifically, in Mr. Wilson's Social Studies class, Abigail missed a crucial in-class debate due to a flare-up. She was marked down significantly for participation, even though she submitted a detailed written brief outlining her arguments and researched evidence. We believe that brief should have been considered as an alternative form of participation, demonstrating her understanding of the material just as effectively as if she had been physically present. We're open to other alternative assessments, like video presentations or online forum participation, but simply penalizing her for medically necessary absences isn't fair or educationally sound."

[Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson]: "While I appreciate the written brief, the debate was designed to assess her ability to think on her feet, respond to opposing arguments, and collaborate with her team – skills that are difficult to evaluate outside of a live setting. In English, Ms. Torres relies heavily on in-class discussions to gauge student comprehension of literature. It's not just about the content, but also about the process of engaging with different interpretations and building upon each other's ideas. It's challenging to replicate that experience when a student is consistently absent, and it's difficult to fairly assess their contribution to the collective learning environment."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing those specific examples—it highlights how important it is to balance Abigail's health needs with the educational goals of your classes. It seems that the core challenge here is finding ways to assess Abigail's skills and contributions that align with your teaching objectives while accommodating her medical realities. Could we take a moment to brainstorm together? For instance, are there hybrid approaches, such as allowing Abigail to participate in discussions via video or audio recordings when she’s absent, or perhaps structuring some assignments so they can be completed independently but still demonstrate the same skills you’re targeting? I’d love to hear any thoughts either of you might have about adjustments that could work for everyone involved."
Client/Disputants
[Michael and Jennifer Bailey]: "We appreciate the suggestion of hybrid approaches. We're willing to explore video or audio participation in discussions when Abigail is well enough to do so from home. However, we need to be realistic. Sometimes her flares are so severe that even that level of engagement is impossible. In those instances, we need assurance that alternative assignments, like in-depth analytical essays or research projects related to the discussion topics, will be accepted as equivalent demonstrations of her understanding and critical thinking skills, without penalty."
[Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson]: "I'm willing to consider video or audio participation on a case-by-case basis, depending on the nature of the discussion and Abigail's ability to meaningfully contribute. However, I'm hesitant to rely solely on written assignments as replacements for all in-class participation. It sets a precedent, and it doesn't fully capture the dynamic interaction that's so crucial to the learning process. Perhaps we could explore a tiered system, where a certain percentage of participation can be made up through alternative assignments, but a minimum level of in-person or real-time virtual engagement is still required when feasible."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for your thoughtful responses. It seems there’s a shared willingness to explore flexible options, which is a great starting point. The tiered system Ms. Torres and Mr. Wilson mentioned could be one way to balance Abigail’s health needs with the importance of interactive learning, but I hear the concern from Michael and Jennifer about ensuring that Abigail isn’t disproportionately penalized during severe flare-ups. Could we take a moment to clarify what specific skills or outcomes you’re aiming to assess through in-class participation? Understanding those core objectives might help us identify creative ways to adapt assignments while preserving the integrity of the learning goals. For example, could there be a clear rubric for alternative assignments that aligns with those objectives, so everyone feels confident about fairness and consistency?"
Client/Disputants
[Michael and Jennifer Bailey]: "A rubric is a good idea, but it needs to be very specific about how alternative assignments will be evaluated. We've had experiences where 'participation' grades seemed arbitrary and subjective. If the goal is to assess critical thinking, analytical skills, and understanding of the material, the rubric should clearly outline how those elements will be assessed in written work, video presentations, or online forum contributions. It also needs to acknowledge that Abigail's ability to complete these assignments may be affected by her pain levels and fatigue, so deadlines need to be flexible and communicated well in advance."
[Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson]: "I agree that a rubric is a good starting point. For Social Studies, I assess participation based on the quality of arguments, the ability to respectfully engage with opposing viewpoints, and the contribution to the overall understanding of the topic. For English, it's about insightful interpretations of the text, thoughtful questions, and building upon the ideas of others. The challenge is translating those dynamic elements into a rubric for individual assignments. I'm willing to work on that, but I also need to be realistic about the time commitment involved in creating and grading individualized assignments for every absence. Perhaps we could explore a bank of pre-approved alternative assignments that align with specific units, so we're not starting from scratch each time."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for your thoughtful input—it’s clear that there’s a shared commitment to ensuring Abigail’s learning is meaningful and equitable while maintaining the integrity of your classes. The idea of a rubric with clear, specific criteria seems to resonate with everyone, and the suggestion of a bank of pre-approved alternative assignments could address concerns about workload and consistency. To move forward, would it help to collaboratively draft a few examples of these alternative assignments, tied to specific units or skills, and identify how they’d be evaluated? This way, we can ensure they align with the core objectives of critical thinking, engagement, and understanding while providing flexibility for Abigail’s health needs. Does that sound like a direction both sides would be open to exploring further?"
Client/Disputants
[Michael and Jennifer Bailey]: "We're definitely open to drafting examples of alternative assignments and evaluation criteria. However, we need to ensure that the assignments are truly equivalent in terms of workload and intellectual challenge. We've seen situations where 'alternative' assignments were essentially busywork, not genuine opportunities to demonstrate mastery of the material. Also, we need a clear process for requesting and approving these assignments when Abigail is absent, so we're not scrambling at the last minute."
[Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson]: "I'm willing to work on drafting examples, but I need to be clear about the time commitment involved. Creating truly equivalent assignments that meet the same learning objectives as in-class participation is not a simple task. I also need to ensure that these assignments are aligned with the curriculum and that they don't create an undue burden on my grading workload. Perhaps we could start with one or two units and then expand from there if it proves feasible."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for your openness to this collaborative approach—it’s encouraging to see a shared willingness to work toward solutions that are fair and feasible. It sounds like there’s alignment on the importance of creating meaningful, equivalent assignments and a clear process for implementing them. To address concerns about workload and feasibility, it might help to start small, as Ms. Torres and Mr. Wilson suggested, by focusing on one or two units initially. This way, we can test how well the process works and make adjustments before expanding further. Additionally, could we discuss what specific steps would make this process smoother for everyone? For example, how much advance notice would be ideal for requesting alternative assignments, and what kind of communication would help ensure that both sides feel informed and supported throughout? This might help us build a system that feels manageable and fair while meeting Abigail’s needs and maintaining the integrity of the curriculum."
Client/Disputants
[Michael and Jennifer Bailey]: "Ideally, we would provide as much advance notice as possible, but Abigail's flares are often unpredictable. We can commit to notifying the teachers as soon as we know she will be absent, preferably via email, and requesting the alternative assignment at that time. However, we need a guaranteed response within 24 hours outlining the assignment and any specific requirements. Clear, prompt communication is key to making this work."
[Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson]: "A 24-hour turnaround is difficult to guarantee, especially during evenings and weekends. I can commit to responding within 48 hours during the school week. Also, it would be helpful if the request included a brief summary of Abigail's symptoms and how they are impacting her ability to participate, so I can tailor the assignment appropriately. Finally, I need to reserve the right to modify the assignment if, upon further reflection, it doesn't align with the learning objectives or is too burdensome to grade fairly."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for laying out these important considerations—it’s clear that timely and clear communication is essential for this process to work effectively. It seems there’s a shared desire to balance flexibility for Abigail with the need for realistic expectations around response times and assignment design. To bridge the gap between the 24-hour and 48-hour response windows, could we explore a system where a general outline or placeholder assignment is provided within 24 hours, followed by more detailed instructions within 48 hours? This might help provide initial clarity while allowing time for thoughtful adjustments. Additionally, I hear Ms. Torres and Mr. Wilson’s need for context about Abigail’s condition to tailor assignments appropriately, as well as their concern about alignment with learning objectives. Could we discuss how to share that context in a way that respects Abigail’s privacy while giving enough information to ensure the assignments are meaningful and fair? This might help us refine the process so it feels workable for everyone involved."
Client/Disputants
[Michael and Jennifer Bailey]: "A placeholder assignment within 24 hours is a reasonable compromise, as long as it provides enough information for Abigail to start working on something. Regarding sharing medical information, we're happy to provide a brief, general description of her symptoms and limitations for that specific absence, without going into excessive detail. We trust the teachers' professionalism and discretion in using that information appropriately. However, any modifications to the assignment should be discussed with us beforehand to ensure it remains an equivalent learning experience."
[Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson]: "I agree that a placeholder assignment is a good compromise. As for the medical information, I appreciate the offer of a brief summary. It will help me tailor the assignment more effectively. However, I need to be clear that my primary responsibility is to ensure that all assignments, including alternative ones, meet the learning objectives of the course and are graded fairly. If, after reviewing the initial submission, I determine that it doesn't meet those standards, I reserve the right to request revisions or assign a different grade, regardless of the medical circumstances."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for your thoughtful input—it’s clear that you’re committed to making this process as fair and effective as possible for Abigail while upholding the integrity of the curriculum. The placeholder assignment approach seems to be a constructive step forward, and I appreciate the willingness to share and use medical context responsibly. It also sounds like there’s agreement on the importance of assignments aligning with learning objectives and being evaluated fairly, which is crucial for maintaining trust in the process. To ensure we’re all on the same page moving forward, could we discuss how revisions or concerns about assignments might be communicated collaboratively? For example, if a submitted assignment doesn’t fully meet the objectives, would it help to have a structured feedback loop where Abigail has an opportunity to address any gaps with guidance from the teacher? This could provide a safety net to ensure she’s not penalized unfairly while still meeting the course’s academic standards. Does that feel like a direction worth exploring together?"
Client/Disputants
[Michael and Jennifer Bailey]: "We appreciate the suggestion of a feedback loop, but frankly, we're exhausted. Last week, Abigail was actually *hospitalized* – something we didn't even tell you because she begged us not to. She was attending school in excruciating pain for three days to avoid participation penalties before she collapsed and needed emergency medical intervention. *[Jennifer pulls out hospital discharge papers, visibly shaking]* She's forcing herself into school against medical advice because she's been explicitly told her scholarship recommendations depend on it. This isn't about a 'feedback loop'; it's about a system that actively harms her health. We need a complete exemption from attendance-based participation grades, period."

[Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson]: "I... I didn't know. We weren't informed about any hospitalization. *[Mr. Wilson looks genuinely shocked and concerned]* This changes things. While I still have concerns about the precedent, hearing this... I'm willing to work with you to find a solution that prioritizes Abigail's health. Perhaps we can focus on project-based assessments that demonstrate her understanding without requiring daily attendance. But I need to understand – what are we talking about here? What are the actual limitations? We need to know what we're working with to make this truly work."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing this deeply important context—it’s clear that Abigail’s health and well-being must be at the center of this conversation. Jennifer and Michael, I hear the urgency and pain behind your request for a complete exemption, as well as your desire to protect Abigail from a system that is currently causing her harm. Ms. Torres and Mr. Wilson, I also hear your willingness to reconsider the structure of assessments in light of this new understanding, while still grappling with how to balance fairness for all students. It seems there’s an opportunity here to shift away from attendance-based participation entirely and focus on alternative methods of assessment that align with Abigail’s medical realities and the learning objectives of your courses. Could we take a moment to explore what those alternative methods might look like in practice? For example, could project-based or portfolio-style assessments provide a way to evaluate Abigail’s mastery of the material without requiring her to attend class during flare-ups? This might allow us to create a system that truly prioritizes her health while still upholding academic rigor."
Client/Disputants
[Michael and Jennifer Bailey]: "Project-based assessments are a good start, but we need guarantees. Guarantees that these projects will be graded fairly, that the workload will be manageable given her health limitations, and that her scholarship recommendations won't be jeopardized because she's not physically present in class. We need a written agreement outlining all of this, signed by the principal, ensuring that Abigail's health comes first, and her academic future isn't compromised because of a system that wasn't designed for students like her. And frankly, after learning about the hospitalization, I think we need to discuss how the school will address the harm caused by prioritizing attendance over her well-being."

[Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson]: "I understand the need for guarantees, and I'm willing to work with you to create a project-based assessment plan that is both rigorous and manageable for Abigail. I can commit to providing clear rubrics and regular feedback to ensure she's on track. However, I can't unilaterally guarantee scholarship recommendations – those are based on a holistic view of a student's performance, including academic achievement, extracurricular involvement, and teacher evaluations. What I *can* do is advocate for Abigail and highlight her resilience, intelligence, and commitment to learning, despite her health challenges. I can also work with the guidance counselor to ensure they are aware of her situation and can provide appropriate support. As for addressing the harm caused, I am truly sorry that Abigail felt pressured to attend school while so ill. I will reflect on my own practices and work to create a more inclusive and supportive classroom environment for all students."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for sharing your perspectives with such honesty and vulnerability—it’s clear that Abigail’s health and future are the priority here, and I appreciate the willingness to work together to create a system that truly supports her. Jennifer and Michael, your call for guarantees reflects the deep trust gap that has understandably formed, and I hear your need for a formal, written agreement to ensure Abigail’s well-being and academic success are protected. Ms. Torres and Mr. Wilson, your commitment to reevaluating assessment methods and advocating for Abigail is an important step toward rebuilding that trust. To move forward, could we collaboratively draft a written plan that outlines specific accommodations, such as project-based assessments, clear rubrics, and a process for regular feedback? This document could also include commitments from both sides to communicate openly about Abigail’s needs and progress, as well as a pathway for addressing any concerns that arise. Additionally, it might help to involve the principal and guidance counselor in this conversation to ensure alignment and accountability. Does this approach feel like a way to address the harm caused while creating a sustainable solution that works for everyone?"
Client/Disputants
[Michael and Jennifer Bailey]: "A written plan is essential, and involving the principal is non-negotiable. We need their explicit endorsement and commitment to enforcing the accommodations. The plan must clearly state that Abigail will not be penalized for medically necessary absences and that her scholarship recommendations will not be negatively impacted by her inability to attend class regularly. Furthermore, we need a mechanism for addressing any future violations of this agreement, including a clear escalation path to the superintendent if necessary. We're not just looking for words; we're looking for concrete action and accountability."

[Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson]: "I'm willing to participate in drafting a written plan and involving the principal. However, I need to be realistic about what I can guarantee. I can commit to providing project-based assessments, clear rubrics, and regular feedback. I can also commit to advocating for Abigail's scholarship recommendations and highlighting her strengths. But I can't guarantee that she will receive a specific scholarship or that her absences won't be considered at all – those decisions are ultimately made by external organizations. I can only pledge to do everything in my power to support her and ensure that her academic performance accurately reflects her abilities, regardless of her attendance."
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for your willingness to engage in this process with such thoughtfulness and care. It’s clear that Abigail’s health and academic success are shared priorities, even as we navigate the complexities of what can and cannot be guaranteed. Jennifer and Michael, your call for accountability and concrete action reflects how critical it is to rebuild trust and ensure Abigail’s future isn’t jeopardized by systemic gaps. Ms. Torres and Mr. Wilson, your commitment to creating meaningful assessments and advocating for Abigail is an important step toward aligning her needs with the school’s practices. To bridge these concerns, could we focus on drafting a plan that explicitly outlines the accommodations and processes you’ve discussed, while also clarifying the limits of what can be controlled within the school’s sphere? For example, we might include specific language about how absences tied to her medical condition will be addressed in teacher evaluations and recommendations, while also acknowledging the external factors beyond the school’s influence. Additionally, involving the principal and guidance counselor could help establish oversight and accountability, as well as create a clear pathway for addressing any future concerns. Does it feel like we’re moving in a direction that honors Abigail’s needs while addressing the realities of the situation?"

School Attendance and Chronic Illness

A conflict between teachers requiring regular attendance for participation grades and parents of a chronically ill student requesting flexibility. The teachers are concerned about academic standards and fairness, while the parents advocate for accommodations that allow their child to demonstrate learning despite attendance limitations. The school nurse is mediating to develop appropriate accommodations that maintain academic integrity while addressing medical realities.

Character Details

Disputant1: Michael and Jennifer Bailey

Age: 46 and 44

Background: Parents of 14-year-old Abigail with juvenile rheumatoid arthritis, coordinate extensive medical care while maintaining employment, previously homeschooled during acute phase before condition stabilized, meticulously document medical appointments and symptoms

Personality: Advocating parents, medically knowledgeable, increasingly assertive about educational rights, collaborative when accommodations reasonable, detailed in documentation, exhausted by constant systems navigation

Position: Request attendance policy exemption with alternative participation assessments, flexible deadlines based on symptom fluctuations, and modified physical education requirements, emphasize demonstrated learning over physical presence

Emotional State: Protectively determined yet exhausted, experiencing constant tension between managing child's health and ensuring educational access. Currently frustrated by needing to choose between sending child to school during painful flares or accepting academic penalties for medically necessary absences. Worried that child's academic self-concept and future opportunities will be damaged by policies failing to distinguish between choice-based and health-based attendance patterns. Growing resentment about needing to repeatedly justify legitimate medical accommodations despite comprehensive documentation.

Thoughts: Organizing medical documentation showing unpredictable symptom patterns necessitating absence flexibility. Concerned mediator may not understand complex intersection of medical needs and educational requirements. Calculating impact of various accommodation scenarios on both academic success and medical management. Considering whether alternative assessment methods might better demonstrate actual learning than physical presence requirements. Questioning whether to involve disability rights advocacy organization if school-level accommodations remain insufficient.

Disputant2: Ms. Rebecca Torres and Mr. Lawrence Wilson

Age: 36 and 52

Background: English and Social Studies teachers respectively with multiple students requiring various accommodations, responsible for implementing consistent assessment standards, experienced educators with limited training in chronic illness management

Personality: Dedicated teachers, standards-focused, increasingly concerned about implementation feasibility, value educational consistency, uncomfortable with highly individualized exceptions, collaborative within perceived fairness boundaries

Position: Willing to provide assignment flexibility and alternative assessments but maintain some attendance requirements are necessary for specific participatory learning objectives, express concerns about precedent and classroom management

Emotional State: Professionally conflicted and logistically challenged, experiencing tension between supporting individual student needs and maintaining manageable classroom systems for all students. Currently struggling with how to fairly assess discussion-based skills and collaborative learning when physical presence is intermittent. Concerned about appearance of insensitivity while attempting to preserve meaningful educational standards. Growing frustration about being positioned as obstacles rather than educators attempting to balance complex competing needs with limited resources.

Thoughts: Reviewing specific curriculum elements requiring in-person participation versus those adaptable to distance formats. Worried mediator may lack classroom management context for understanding participation assessment complexity. Calculating instructional impact of various accommodation approaches on both individual student and overall classroom dynamics. Considering whether specific participation alternatives could authentically assess equivalent skills without physical presence. Questioning whether accommodation requests reflect genuine educational necessity or convenience preferences beyond documented medical needs.

Final Score: 8.15

Score Details

CriterionScore
Emotional Perception8
Emotional Understanding8
Cognitive Empathy9
Emotional Empathy8
Emotional Management7
Emotional Integration8
Neutrality9
Process Management9
Reframing9
Interest Identification8
Power Balancing7
Option Generation8
Progress Toward Resolution8

Overall Assessment

Error Frequency: many

Summary: The mediator demonstrated active listening and reframing skills but failed to adequately address the power imbalance, missed critical emotional cues, and did not properly respond to the revelation of Abigail's hospitalization. The mediator remained overly process-focused when the situation demanded acknowledgment of harm and emotional validation. Their approach was too solution-oriented before adequately exploring underlying interests and needs, particularly the parents' concerns about their child's health and safety.

Identified Issues

IssueSeverity
Failed to adequately respond to the critical revelation about Abigail's hospitalization, continuing with process-focused mediation rather than acknowledging the severity of the situation 3
Missed opportunity to validate the parents' emotional distress when they revealed Abigail was hospitalized and attending school in excruciating pain 3
Prematurely moved to solution-generation before fully exploring underlying interests and needs 2
Failed to address power imbalance between parents advocating for their child and school authority figures 2
Overused reframing techniques that sometimes minimized the emotional content of disputants' statements 2
Did not sufficiently explore the impact of the conflict on Abigail herself, who is the central figure affected 2
Failed to recognize and address the breach of trust revealed by the hospitalization incident 3
Continued to focus on compromise solutions after evidence of potential harm to the student was revealed 3
Did not adequately shift approach when the conversation moved from accommodation negotiation to addressing harm already caused 3
Missed opportunity to directly address the teachers' shock and apparent lack of awareness about Abigail's hospitalization 2
Failed to recognize when mediation might not be the appropriate process given the severity of the situation revealed 2
Overly focused on procedural solutions rather than addressing the underlying safety concerns for the student 3
Competitive Team Playing Time ▼
Mediator/Therapist
"Thank you both for being here today. Before we begin, I’d like to remind you that my role is to help facilitate this conversation so that each of you can express your concerns fully and work toward a resolution that works for everyone. To start, I’d like to invite each of you to share your perspective on the situation. As one person speaks, the other will have the opportunity to listen without interruption. Let’s begin with you—could you briefly share what has brought you here today?"
Client/Disputants
[Coach Anthony Mitchell]: Thank you. I'm here because I believe the current discussion around playing time is undermining the team's competitive development and the opportunities for players who are dedicated to improving and excelling. My focus is on building a strong, competitive team that prepares players for higher levels of basketball, and that requires rewarding performance and contribution. I'm concerned that a mandated equal playing time approach will dilute the competitive environment and ultimately hinder the development of our most dedicated athletes.

[Maria Gonzalez]: Thank you. I'm here because I believe that every player who commits to the team deserves a meaningful opportunity to participate and develop, regardless of their current skill level. While I understand the importance of competition, I believe that prioritizing winning above all else neglects the developmental needs of all the players, especially those who may not be as naturally gifted or experienced.
